content:
ASIA-PAC

Fonterra reports December New Zealand collections at 176.1mln vs. Prev. 186.3mln Y/Y, Australia collections at 16.1mln vs. Prev. 12.6mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT) Q4 Pilbara iron ore shipments 90.0mln tons vs. Exp. 89.7mln tons, Prev. 87.7mln tons Y/Y. (Newswires)


UK

BOE’s external member Tenreyro said that at December meeting, she saw 'ample time' before the BOE would need to raise rates and expects a couple more hikes over next three years if economy performs as expected. (Newswires)

UK PM May is planning a speech to outline Brexit policy next month, while reports also stated that the EU withdrawal bill is expected to move to the House of Lords this week and pass. (Newswires)

EU is said to toughen conditions for a post Brexit deal. (FT)

 

EU

ECB's Hansson said that QE could be ended in one step without any problems. He also suggested that QE could end after September if the economy & inflation develop as now expected. He also noted that the Euro’s appreciation not a threat to inflation up until now, its rise should not be overdramatized. He is also of the belief that there is a need to adjust ECB communication; and that the ECB should discuss 'intensively' how to change its language, and suggested that the ECB should adjust its policy guidance before summer. Hansson is also of the belief that the ECB should hike rates a "few times" before starting to reduce the size of its balance sheet. (Boersen-Zeitung)

German SPD party leader Schulz is `optimistic' that the majority will vote for talks with Merkel. (Newswires)

EU Trade Balance NSA (Nov) EUR 26.3B vs. Exp. EUR 22.4bln (Prev. EUR 18.9bln)


FX

The greenback started the week where it left off, lower, despite a lack of fundamental catalysts, against a backdrop of lower liquidity with the US out for Martin Luther King Jr Day. USD/JPY dropped below 111.00 and briefly below 110.50. Bank of Japan Governor Kuroda spoke overnight, and although he mentioned that QQE with YCC will continue for as long as necessary, he did appear slightly more upbeat about the outlook for prices. The next major risk event for the JPY will be next week’s BoJ decision, with various source reports suggesting that the Bank will mark up its FY2018 growth estimate.

Meanwhile EUR/USD burst through 1.2200, topping out just shy of 1.2300, with barrier option defence in front of the figure being touted; we last trade just below 1.2260. Hawkish comments from the ECB’s Hansson – who said QE could be ended in one step without any problems, and could end after September if economy & inflation develop as now expected – helped to push EUR within a whisker of the 1.23 handle. GBP/USD continued to move higher, printing above 1.3800 at one point, in turn registering a fresh post-Brexit highs. Key UK risk events this week include tomorrow’s inflation data and Friday’s retail sales release. AUD and NZD have both continued their respective advances against the greenback, while the CAD underperformed. The loonie still managed to print gains against the USD, with USD/CAD sitting above 1.24. Traders await Wednesday’s BoC decision, with rates markets pricing in a circa 90% chance of a 25bps hike.

A Bundesbank spokeswoman said that the Bundesbank has not yet invested reserves in CNY following earlier reports citing Bundesbank's Dombret, which suggested that the bank will add the CNY into its currency reserves. (Newswires)

The Bank of France has invested some of its FX reserves in Chinese yuan. (Les Echos)
 

COMMODITIES

Trade in crude was thin due to a US market holiday, leaving crude free to advance amid a weaker US dollar. Brent managed to break through the $70 figure, while WTI is now flirting with the $65 mark. Fundamental news was thin, with traders latching on to comments from a few major oil producers, which called on OPEC to continue with its output supply curbs despite prices recently rising to multi-year highs.

EARLY US MARKET WRAP: USD begins the weak on the back foot; hawkish Hansson
content:
NOTE: US MARKETS WERE CLOSED FOR THE MARTIN LUTHER KING NATIONAL HOLIDAY

CENTRAL BANK SPEAK: Tenreyro’s first speech; Hawkish Hansson

ECB's Hansson said that QE could be ended in one step without any problems. He also suggested that QE could end after September if the economy & inflation develop as now expected. He also noted that the Euro’s appreciation not a threat to inflation up until now, its rise should not be overdramatized. He is also of the belief that there is a need to adjust ECB communication; and that the ECB should discuss 'intensively' how to change its language, and suggested that the ECB should adjust its policy guidance before summer. Hansson is also of the belief that the ECB should hike rates a "few times" before starting to reduce the size of its balance sheet. EUR strengthened on his comments, before paring back slightly.

Although she has given interviews and appeared before the UK Treasury Select Committee, BOE’s external member Tenreyro delivered her first actual speech as an MPC member. Tenreyro said that at December meeting, she saw 'ample time' before the BOE would need to raise rates, expects a couple more hikes over next three years if economy performs as expected. Sterling was little changed after her comments.

EQUITIES: EMINI S&P closed +5.75 at 2,794.50; EMINI Nasdaq 100 closed +5 6780.25; Mini Dow closed +136 at 25937

US equity futures traversed sideways in thin trade. European shares were mixed/slightly lower on Monday, with cyclical stocks weighed on.

In the UK, focus was on Carillion, the second-largest government contractor, after the company collapsed. It’s rivals Serco, Kier and Interserve were higher, though Balfour Beatty – which has some JVs with the company – was lower.  

Tomorrow, key US earnings will be in the spotlight, with the likes of UnitedHealth, Citigroup, Charles Schwab and Markit on the earnings slate.

FOREX: USD down 0.6% heading into APAC trade

The greenback has started the week where it left off, lower, despite a lack of fundamental catalysts, against a backdrop of lower liquidity with the US out for Martin Luther King day. The DXY last trades at 90.50 there or thereabouts.

USD/JPY dropped below 111.00, and now trades below the 110.50 mark. Bank of Japan Governor Kuroda spoke overnight, and although he mentioned that QQE with YCC will continue for as long as necessary, he did appear slightly more upbeat about the outlook for prices. The next major risk event for the JPY will be next week’s BoJ decision, with various source reports suggesting that the Bank will mark up its FY2018 growth estimate.

Meanwhile EUR/USD burst through 1.2200, topping out just shy of 1.2300, with barrier option defence in front of the figure being touted; we last trade just below 1.2260. Hawkish comments from the ECB’s Hansson – who said QE could be ended in one step without any problems, and could end after September if economy & inflation develop as now expected – helped to push EUR within a whisker of the 1.23 handle.

GBP/USD continued to move higher, printing above 1.3800 at one point, in turn registering a fresh post-Brexit highs. Key UK risk events this week include tomorrow’s inflation data and Friday’s retail sales release.

The AUD and NZD have both continued their respective advances against the greenback, while the CAD underperformed. The loonie still managed to print gains against the USD, with USD/CAD sitting above 1.24. Traders await Wednesday’s BoC decision, with rates markets pricing in a circa 90% chance of a 25bps hike.

CRUDE: Crude trades higher at the start of the week in thin trade

Trade in crude was thin due to a US market holiday, leaving crude free to advance amid a weaker US dollar. Brent managed to break through the $70 figure, while WTI is now flirting with the $65 mark.

Fundamental news was thin, with traders latching on to comments from a few major oil producers, which called on OPEC to continue with its output supply curbs despite prices recently rising to multi-year highs.

subject: FX Daily Wrap: USD Lower Again In Thin Holiday Trade
content:
The greenback has started the week where it left off, lower, despite a lack of fundamental catalysts, against a backdrop of lower liquidity with the US out for Martin Luther King day. The DXY last trades at 90.50 there or thereabouts.

USD/JPY dropped below 111.00 before finding support ahead of 110.50. Bank of Japan Governor Kuroda spoke overnight, and although he mentioned that QQE with YCC will continue for as long as necessary, he did appear slightly more upbeat about the outlook for prices. The next major risk event for the JPY will be next week’s BoJ decision, with various source reports suggesting that the Bank will mark up its FY2018 growth estimate.

Meanwhile EUR/USD burst through 1.2200, topping out just shy of 1.2300, with barrier option defence in front of the figure being touted; we last trade just below 1.2260.

GBP/USD continued to move higher, printing above 1.3800 at one point, in turn registering a fresh post-Brexit highs. Key UK risk events this week include tomorrow’s inflation data and Friday’s retail sales release.

The AUD and NZD have both continued their respective advances against the greenback, while the CAD underperformed. The loonie still managed to print gains against the USD, with USD/CAD sitting at 1.2425, off of the 1.2405 low. Traders await Wednesday’s BoC decision, with rates markets pricing in a circa 90% chance of a 25bps hike.

subject: FX LATEST: Dollar roundly flogged again
content: It’s almost a case of pick any top or bottom, as the absence of US traders and depth leaves Usd sellers with little in the way of bidding interest or buy orders to stall moves one way or the other. The DXY has now slipped below 90.500, and to recap 90.251 is a support of sorts, but 90.000 looks more likely to give Dollar bears something to at least think about. Turning to currency pairs, Eur/Usd has now surpassed 2 of the December 2014 peaks ahead of 1.2300 and looks intent of testing the next one at 1.2302, but 1.2350 could prove more of an obstacle. Cable is above 1.3800 and one bank has 1.3835 in mind, while Usd/Jpy is testing 110.50 again. Usd/Chf has broken the resolve of chart buyers at 0.9630 and 0.9599 is next, Aud/Usd is back up near best levels ahead of 0.8000 and Nzd/Usd only a few pips off 0.7300, while Usd/Cad is on the brink of 1.2400 vs 1.2355 on January 5th when Canadian jobs data blew away consensus vs the NFP disappointment.

subject: Balfour Beatty (BBY LN) expects cash outflow to be in a range of GBP 35-45mln following the collapse of Carillion (CLLN LN)
EU MID SESSION UPDATE – European stocks off to a slow start as the USD continues to fall
content:
European equity markets have started the week in negative territory, taking a breather after the gains seen since the start of the year. The UK construction and management company Carillion was in focus after the company was forced to go into voluntary liquidation as talks to rescue the company failed, however, trading in their shares was suspended. Serco shares rallied over 3% as markets bet that the company should be able to benefit from the collapse of Carillion, while Carillion supplier Speedy Hire fell over 10%. GKN shares have started the week positively after reports that they are considering spinning off a unit to fend off takeover interest and as Melrose said it’s planning to meet with shareholders following their rejected takeover offer.

The USD has started the week where it left off: lower. USD/JPY bore the brunt of the weakness, dropping below 111.00 before finding support ahead of 110.50. BoJ Governor Kuroda spoke overnight and although he mentioned that QQE with YCC will continue for as long as necessary, the BoJ Governor appeared slightly more upbeat about the outlook for prices. Meanwhile EUR/USD burst through 1.2200 and GBP/USD trades at its highest level since the UK voted to leave the EU.

The weaker USD has benefitted precious metals with gold higher and palladium now trading at a record high. Base metals also gained with LME copper up over 2% on the LME and zinc up to a 10-year high. WTI and Brent crude futures are both a touch lower as Brent failed to make a clean break above USD 70/bbl. Volumes are expected to remain light today owing to the Martin Luther King holiday in the US.

In Fixed Income markets, Bunds and Gilts both extended gains before fading to stand some 20 ticks above parity, with the former seeing further strength on a break of Friday’s Eurex session high to reach 160.76 (+38 ticks on the day), but unable to really challenge the next resistance area on some intraday or short term charts between 160.85-90. 0.5% in 10 year cash is now support rather than psychological resistance and the level is holding, while Gilts probably saw some selling ahead of 124.00 as the Liffe high so far is 123.97 (+37 ticks). Turnover remains light and will likely stay subdued without US participants, but this could result in some exaggerated price action/moves. UST futures are trading, but again amidst low volumes and modestly firmer with a slight flattening bias for choice.

subject: Fixed Income: EU bonds lose some momentum
content: Bunds and Gilts both extended gains before fading to stand some 20 ticks above parity, with the former seeing further strength on a break of Friday’s Eurex session high to reach 160.76 (+38 ticks on the day), but unable to really challenge the next resistance area on some intraday or short term charts between 160.85-90. As noted earlier, 0.5% in 10 year cash is now support rather than psychological resistance and the level is holding, while Gilts probably saw some selling ahead of 124.00 as the Liffe high so far is 123.97 (+37 ticks). Turnover remains light and will likely stay subdued without US participants, but this could result in some exaggerated price action/moves. UST futures are trading, but again amidst low volumes and modestly firmer with a slight flattening bias for choice.

subject: FX Morning Colour: Usd travails extend into 3rd week of 2018
content:
DXY

The Dollar continues to slide, with the Index not seeing any real psychological or even sentimental support on its way down through 91.000, and only just holding above 90.500 (for now at least). The latter is the obvious nearest objective, before support around 90.442 and 90.251, as the Greenback loses more ground against all its G10 and other major rivals, plus commodities and EM currencies. The CNY hit its strongest level vs the Usd after the PBoC’s fix and Germany’s Buba said the Chinese unit will become a reserve currency. Usd/Jpy has declined through key tech support at 110.84 to test bids ahead of 110.50, with option activity now targeting strikes much lower down (via 1 month expiries especially) given little significant on the charts before 109.50. The Eur has rallied beyond 1.2200 with relative ease, but may encounter a bit more resistance approaching a series of December 2014 peaks around 1.2252-56, 1.2273 and 1.2302, as CFTC data shows another record rise in spec longs (circa 144.7k contracts or 21.5 bn in cash terms). Aud and Nzd now above 0.7950 and 0.7275 vs their Dollar counterpart, with the Kiwi eyeing 0.7298 just before the next big figure. Cable has climbed through 1.3750, but slightly lagging as Eur/Gbp tests 0.8900, while Usd/Chf is sitting just below 0.9650 and also underperforming vs the Eur with the cross hovering around 1.1800. Usd/Cad just above 1.2400 and Usd/Mxn around 18.8750, with the Loonie and Peso both benefiting from supportive NAFTA vibes (US President Trump said to be softening his stance somewhat).

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE HAS NOW FINISHED, PLEASE REVERT BACK TO YOUR ORIGINAL CHANNEL FOR COVERAGE ON THE UK & EUROPEAN SESSION

subject: Bunds: slow grinding bid, Gilts (and STIRs) tag along
content: The 10 year German debt future is probing higher off the Eurex open within a 160.42-61 range vs last Friday’s 160.38 close, but with little real conviction other than consolidative trade following last week’s net losses on hawkish ECB minutes and various external impulses that weighed on fixed (supply, upbeat data and broad Usd losses in FX markets). The benchmark yield breached 0.5%, but stopped well short of the next upside area around 0.62-0.63% targeted by many tech studies and has subsequently retreated to retest the psychological level, which represents a pivot point and will likely determine whether futures rebound further or reverse course again. Monday’s agenda is typically light in terms of data and of course volumes are thinner than normal due to the US MLK holiday. Turning to Liffe, Gilts have also re-joined the fray on a firmer footing between 123.66-80 vs the 123.60 previous close, while Short Sterling and Euribor strips are flat to 2 ticks ahead, with the latter perhaps drawing some comfort from comments by ECB’s Weidmann downplaying near term rate hike expectations (after late 2018 tightening prospects rose to circa 70% post-December’s minutes).

subject: Carillion (CLLN LN) says talks have been unsuccessful and the company has entered voluntary liquidation with immediate effect
DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: GKN (GKN LN) – Co. is exploring the option of selling its aerospace business to fend off more potential approaches
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

15th January 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets began the week mostly positive as optimism trickled through from last Friday’s performance on Wall St in which all majors posted fresh record levels once again as earnings season got underway and where the energy sector was bolstered by upside in crude. ASX 200 (+0.1%) traded positive with outperformance in gold miners after the precious metal which edged a 5th weekly consecutive gain, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was also in the green but well off best levels as a firmer JPY pared the strength seen in the index at the open. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) eyed record closing highs and the Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) was choppy after the PBoC announced to lend nearly CNY 400bln via its Medium-term Lending Facility, which briefly eased mainland jitters arising from discouraging lending data and further reports of increased financial sector oversight to curb risks.

FTSE

GKN (GKN LN) – Co. is exploring the option of selling its aerospace business to fend off more potential approaches after the offer by Melrose last week. (Times)

HSBC (HSBA LN) – The co. said some UK cards were sent out with chip errors however they said there were no security risks and the cards were replaced. (Newswires)

Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN) – Co. said to seek USD 700mln from L’Orange arm sale. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Carillion (CLLN LN) – Despite a late bid to rescue the company, administrators are preparing to take action and directors were making a final appeal to stop the company from collapse. (Guardian/Newswires)  

M&C Hotels (MNC LN) – The co.’s suitor has hired Georgeson to drum up support for its bid for the co. (Newswires)

BROKER RECOMMENDATIONS

ROTORK (ROR LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

LADBROKES CORAL (LCL LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN

JOHNSON MATTHEY (JMAT LN) RAISED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. CEO Cryan sees a small after tax loss in 2017 and he is convinced the business model is on the right path. (Newswires)

Metro (B4B GY) – Q1 revenue up 0.2% to EUR 10.1bln, up 0.8% like for like. Co. says Q1 sales in line with outlook for FY 2017/18. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Co. says 2017 brand sales rose to a record 6.23mln car in 2017 with US brand sales up 5.2%. The automaker confirms agreements with Canadian class counsel resolving 20k diesel engine claims for CAD 290.5mln. (Newswires) Separately, the co. plans to spend more than USD 3.3bln from 2018 to 2020 to develop and produce more vehicles in North Americaand has also launched a new Jetta compact car. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Fraport (FRA GY) – Co. says Frankfurt air passenger traffic up 7.3% in December, cargo down 4.5%. (Newswires)

CAC

Aeroports de Paris (ADP FP) – Co. reports passenger traffic was up 4.5% in 2017. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. is in talks with German prosecutors to end an investigation into the sale of Eurofighter jets to Austria in exchange for a settlement of up to EUR 80mln. Separately, the company has been ordered to pay a EUR 100mln fine over a missile sale to Taiwan in 1992. (Newswires)

Air France KLM (AF FP) – Co. denied it has made an offer for Alitalia after reports of a joint bid with EasyJet (EZJ LN) for the company. (Newswires)

LVMH (MC FP) – Co.’s watch and jewellery sales rose more than 10% in 2017, according to the head of the co.’s Hublot brand, (Newswires)

PAN-EUROPE

OVS (OVS IM) – European private equity firm BC Partners is considering selling its 17.8% stake in the co., according to sources. (Corriere della Sera)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – The co. has pushed back a deadline for binding bids for its broadcasting services unit Persidera, according to sources. (Newswires)

BROKER RECOMMENDATIONS

TENARIS (TEN IM) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

ASML (ASML NA) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

ENDESA (ELE SM) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM SELL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

SMI

Kuehne + Nagel (KNIN SW) – Co. said it and Temasek are creating a joint venture for investment and logistics technology startups. (Newswires)

Watch makers – Swiss watch exporters are expected to have risen by approx.. 3% in 2017, according to the head of the Swiss Watch Federation. (Schweiz am Wochenende)

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER RECOMMENDATIONS

SUBSEA 7 (SUBC NO) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT MACQUARIE

FORTUM (FUM1V FH) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

US

EQUITIES: SPX +0.66% at 2786, DJI +0.88% at 25800, NDX +0.75% at 6758

The equities rally continued, with major US bourses printing fresh record highs at the end of the week, as Q4 earnings season gets underway. Banks began reporting their numbers, with JPMorgan reporting a top and bottom-line beat; Wells Fargo, however, could only beat on the Adj EPS front, with revenues falling slightly short of expectations. The former’s trading revenues were glum, as expected, with fixed income trading off by over 30%, while equities trading revenues were flat. Consumer discretionary led the gains after retail sales increased. Energy was also higher, tracking crude prices. On the other end of the scale, utilities were the laggard, once again.

Top performers: Consumer cyclicals +1.0%, Energy +0.8%, Industrials +0.7%

Bottom sectors: Utilities -0.4%, Consumer non-cyclicals +0.1%, Materials +0.1%

subject: Indian WPI (Dec) Y/Y 3.60% vs. Exp. 4.00% (Prev. 3.93%)
DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: USD softens to 3yr low, while the Asia-Pac region trades modestly in the green
content:
15th January 2018

  • Asian equity markets modestly in the green with sentiment buoyed from Friday’s Wall St. close.
  • PBoC sets the strongest CNY since May’16, supporting AUD and NZD, while USD softens to 3yr low.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include BoE’s Tenreyro and as a reminder US markets are closed for MLK day.

ASIA

Asia equity markets began the week mostly positive as optimism trickled through from last Friday’s performance on Wall St in which all majors posted fresh record levels once again as earnings season got underway and where the energy sector was bolstered by upside in crude. ASX 200 (+0.1%) traded positive with outperformance in gold miners after the precious metal which edged a 5th weekly consecutive gain, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was also in the green but well off best levels as a firmer JPY pared the strength seen in the index at the open. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) eyed record closing highs and the Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) was choppy after the PBoC announced to lend nearly CNY 400bln via its Medium-term Lending Facility, which briefly eased mainland jitters arising from discouraging lending data and further reports of increased financial sector oversight to curb risks. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with demand subdued by a positive risk tone in Japan and after an uneventful Rinban announcement, in which the BoJ maintained purchase amounts.

PBoC announced CNY 398bln via Medium-term Lending Facility with 1yr loans offered at 3.25% and said there has been a relatively large drop in total liquidity in the banking system due to tax and RRR payments, as well as maturing loans. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 80bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 70bln via 14-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4574 (Prev. 6.4932)

 
UK

UK Rightmove House Prices (Jan) M/M 0.7% (Prev. -2.6%). (Newswires)
UK Rightmove House Prices (Jan) Y/Y 1.1% (Prev. 1.2%)

UK Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is said to have warned allies that Brexit is far from certain. (The Sun)

Dutch Finance Ministry said there was no new agreement between Spain and the Netherlands on British departure from EU. (Newswires) This follows reports on Friday that the two countries agreed to seek a soft Brexit.

Spain and the UK are set to hold talks regarding Gibraltar following Brexit, according to press reports. (Newswires)

 

EU

ECB’s Weidmann said the chances of an imminent move in ECB's interest rates is small at the moment. (Newswires)

Germany SPD party leaders said they will seek to push for improvement on a coalition agreement with German Chancellor Merkel’s conservatives, while there were also reports that German social democrats in Saxony-Anhalt state reportedly rejected a German coalition with Merkel's conservatives. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Belgium ratings at 'AA/A-1+'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

DBRS confirmed Italy at BBB (high); Stable Trend. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, USD continued to weaken against its major counterparts in which antipodeans also benefitted as a proxy, after the PBoC set its firmest fix since May 2016. This pushed USD/CNH to below 6.4400, while reports that the Bundesbank’s decision to include CNY as a currency reserve, would also be welcomed by Chinese officials in their efforts to promote internationalization of the currency. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was another fallout from the greenback’s woes as the pair tripped through stops on a break below 111.00 and amid comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda who stuck to the usual rhetoric of maintaining current policy, although some noted the absence of reference to ‘powerful easing’. In addition, NAFTA currencies also remained firm with USD/MXN at its lowest in a month after reports that President Trump is said to be softening his attitude towards NAFTA and taking risks of withdrawal more seriously.

Bundesbank's Dombret said they have decided to include CNY in currency reserves. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly higher overnight as they benefited from USD weakness in which WTI crude futures marginally extended on recent gains and Brent crude approached closer towards a test of the USD 70/bbl level. Elsewhere, gold prices continued its ascent after having posted a 5th consecutive weekly advance last Friday, while copper led the broad gains across the complex with prices higher by nearly 2%.   

US Baker Hughes Total (12 Jan) 939 (Prev. 924). (Newswires)

Nigeria’s Oil Minister said that we shouldn’t get too bullish or excited yet regarding oil price increase and that things can change overnight. (Newswires) 

Reports stated that Iraq, UAE, Qatar and Oman were all calling for OPEC and Non-OPEC producers to stick to the output cut deal. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea reportedly indicated it can roll back the decision to attend the Winter Olympics. (Newswires)


US

Although Treasury yields were slightly higher on the day (with the exception of 30s, which were unchanged), major curves flattened; most notably, the 2s30s curve, by c.3.6bps. 2s yields rose by around 3bps on the day following a decent core CPI data print, which has nudged the probability of three Fed hikes in 2018 slightly higher. Corporate supply had been healthy for the week, with high-grade raising $32bln, according to Reuters. US 10-Year T-Note Futures settle 6 ticks lower at 122-30.

Fed's Rosengren (Non-Voter, Soft Hawk) said more than three 2018 hikes are likely and that Fed should consider updating policy framework in which an inflation range of 1.5%-3.0% might be appropriate. (Newswires)

Fed’s Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) said he hopes inflation is moving reliably towards target and that he would like to see more data. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (Non-Voter, Soft Hawk) repeated that he expects 2 rate hikes in 2018. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he does not know if there will be a government shutdown. (Newswires)

US President Trump commented via Twitter that he doesn’t believe Democrats want a deal on immigration and are all talk and no action, while he added that a great opportunity has been missed. However, there were also reports that suggested some Republicans were still hopeful regarding a possible DACA deal. (Twitter/Newswires)

US President Trump is said to be softening his attitude towards NAFTA and taking risks of withdrawal more seriously, according to several sources who have spoken with Trump. (Newswires)

Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) eyed record closing highs and the Shanghai Comp. ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Last Friday's Wall St records just about inspires modest gains in Asia
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week mostly positive as optimism trickles through from last Friday’s performance on Wall St in which all majors posted fresh record levels once again as earnings season got underway and where the energy sector was bolstered by upside in crude. ASX 200 (+0.1%) is positive with gold miners outperforming in Australia after advances in the precious metal which edged a 5th weekly consecutive gain on Friday, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) is also in the green but well off best levels as a firmer JPY pares the strength seen in the index at the open. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) closes in on a record high and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) also found support after the PBoC announced to lend nearly CNY 400bln via its Medium-term Lending Facility, which helped shrug off early mainland jitters arising from discouraging lending data.

In FX markets, USD continues to weaken against its major counterparts with antipodeans also benefitting as a proxy, after the PBoC set its firmest fix since May 2016 which pushed USD/CNH to below 6.4400. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was another fallout from the greenback’s woes as the pair tripped through stops on a break below 111.00 and amid comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda who stuck to the usual rhetoric of maintaining current policy, although some noted the absence of reference to ‘powerful easing’. In addition, NAFTA currencies also remain firm with USD/MXN at its lowest in a month after reports that President Trump is said to be softening his attitude towards NAFTA and taking risks of withdrawal more seriously.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with demand subdued by a positive risk tone in Japan and after an uneventful Rinban announcement, in which the BoJ maintained purchase amounts in 5yr-10yr, 10yr-25yr and 25yr+ maturities.
